titleStmt.title: M48. Anon. Typescript fragment, with the author's ms. corrections, unsigned and undated. 2p
titleStmt.author: Virginia Woolf

publicationStmt.authority: The Estate of Virginia Woolf, administered by the Society of Authors

msIdentifier.repository: Henry W. and Albert A. Berg Collection of English and American Literature

physDesc.p: Anon. Typescript fragment, with the author's ms. corrections, unsigned and undated. 2p

handNote.p: Holograph writing by the documents' main hand, Virginia Woolf.

correction.p: Apparent errors have been explicitly corrected in / tags, wrapped in a element.

normalization.p: Where appropriate, spelling and punctuation have been modernised using / tags, wrapped in a element.

interpretation.p: Names and references to places and literary works have been wrapped in tags which link to annotations and secondary material.

projectDesc.p: Text encoded as part of 'The Digital "Anon": A Digital Genetic Edition of Virginia Woolf's Final Essays'. This project, funded by Leverhulme Grant ECF-2022-602, seeks to construct a TEI-XML based digital edition of the drafts of 'Anon' and 'The Reader', among the final documents Woolf wrote before her death.

prefixDef.p: In the context of this project, private URIs with the prefix "psn" point to Person elements in the project's `personography.xml` file

p.lb:
For many centuries
after afte Britain became an island "
the historian says, "the untamed forest was king."
He goes on to say that amillions of birds, perched on
the top of those matted branches, sang their choruses.
Only the skin clad hunters in the clearings heard the song.

The tree
had h to be felled; and a hut made from its
branches , before the human voice sang too.
By a bank as I lay
Musing myself alone, j hey ho!
A birdes voice
Did me rejoice,
Singing before the day
And me thought in her lay
She said, winter was past, hey ho!

lb.del: The first songs are out of door songs; because there
was no comfort indoors, little light, and no books.

p.lb:
The voice that
brok broke the
silnec silence of the forests was like a
birds bird's voice, singing out of doors. It was the voice of
Anon. He had no comfort indoors, little light

and no books. He had
n no name. Some one heard the song

and
rmember d remembered it, for it was later written down. TheThusthe singer
had his audience thus; but the audience was so little
interested in his name that he never thought to give it.
The audience took part too in the song. "Terly, terlow"

they sang: and "By, by lullay " filling in
th the pauses
